column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*All travellers: The Foreign Ministry website is regularly updated with details of the latest entry requirements.
If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Georgia by air without needing to test or quarantine. You will need to present a COVID-19 vaccine certificate confirming receipt of two full doses of the vaccine (or one dose in the case of Johnson & Johnson). If you arrive by land or sea, you will additionally need to present a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours.
Find out if you qualify as fully vaccinated in Georgia on The Foreign Ministry website. You should arrange to take a private test.
Proof of vaccination status: Georgia will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued. Your final vaccine dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to travel. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status. Residents of Georgia can also use a COVID-19 Green Pass issued by the National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) to demonstrate their vaccine status.
*If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, you can enter Georgia provided your travel to Georgia originates in one of the other countries listed on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs website. You must travel by air and submit a travel history in advance (application form on https://mfa.gov.ge/), present a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours and take a further PCR test at your own expense on your third day in Georgia.
If you’ve had COVID-19 in the last six months: If you present proof of having been infected with COVID within the previous 100 days and have had the first jab in a two-dose vaccination process, you do not need to test or quarantine to enter Georgia if you arrive by air. If you arrive by land or sea, you will need to present a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours.
If you were infected more than 100 days previously or have no proof of recovery or vaccination status, you can enter Georgia provided your travel to Georgia originates in one of the other countries listed on the Foreign Ministry’s website. You must travel by air and submit a travel history in advance, present on arrival a negative PCR test taken within the previous 72 hours and take a further PCR test at your own expense on your third day in Georgia.
*Children and young people: Children aged 9 and under follow the rules for fully vaccinated travellers to enter Georgia and are exempted from any PCR tests.
*If you’re transiting Georgia: There are no separate rules for transiting Georgia. You should follow the regulations outlined above depending on your vaccination status.
*Exemptions: There are no exemptions to Georgia’s entry requirements.

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Georgia: Inter-city and municipal public transport and taxis are operating normally. Face masks must be worn in all public transport and taxis.
*Accommodation: Hotels and rental accommodation are open. Face masks must be worn when entering public spaces inside hotels and rental accommodation. *Public spaces and services: It is mandatory to wear masks in public places indoors (shops, hotels etc) and outdoors. Failing to do so can result in a 20 Lari fine for an individual or 500 Lari for a legal entity.
Social distancing requirements remain in place. Large celebratory gatherings such as weddings remain banned.Systematic COVID-19 testing of staff working in trading, catering and teaching professions is taking place.
You can find full details of the latest restrictions from the Government of Georgia. *If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
